title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046ab40f25d1.74493147.png) If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***mc_dna_eq_str.pdb***: structure with DNA in relaxed state. Can be visualized in NGL viewer ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf8a0359424.68527922.png) If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***mc_dna_str.dcd***: trajectory file (in GROMACS format). Can be visualized in NGL viewer together with 'mc_dna_str.pdb' * ***mc_dna_str.pdb***: first structure of the ensemble. Can be visualized it in NGL viewer * ***mc_dna_str.top***: topology file for DNA trajectory; necessary to visualize trajectory in NGL viewer. It is also necessary for Input to the analysis tool of nuclear acid structures and trajectories *NAflex*

title: Help
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. Furthermore, the obtained structure and/or trajectory can be used as an input to **NAflex** for a more detailed analysis. ![{w:600}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046f74a7aa28.10745002.png)

title: Results
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In the ‘View Results’ section, you can download all the analysis results and the structure/trajectory in a compressed tar.gz file. In this file you can find the figures of the bending analysis: The results depend on the type of operations the user chooses to execute MC-DNA. [Create Structure](#anchor1) [Create Trajectory](#anchor2)   If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***create_str01.png***: Bending distribution of all 5/10bp segments of the simulated DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010). The x-axis shows the bending in degree, the y-axis the density. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041a4eb2ea41.86588142.png) * ***create_str02.png***: Bending of 5/10bp segments along the DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010) (Note: n here is the last bp of the segment bnx(10) ). The x-axis shows the index of the basepair, the y-axis shows the bending in degree. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041bb9575091.47548585.png)   If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***create_traj01.png***: same as create_str01.png, here all snapshots of the trajectory are taken into accoutn. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cbbb2f0b4.02405084.png) * ***create_traj02.png***: same as create_str02.png, averaged over all snapshots of the trajectory. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cea5aed73.99266157.png) NOTE: For a more detailed analysis apart from bending use the output pdb or trajectory files as an input to *NAflex*.

title: Inputs
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References **MC-DNA** can be computed from a **DNA sequence**. # Accepted input file combinations **Combination ** *(File Type - Data Type)* ``` TXT DNA sequence ``` To run **MC-DNA** a `txt` file representing a **DNA sequence** needs to be selected in the **user workspace**. Associated to the **txt file**, at the right part of the workspace (in the same row), an **Actions button** represented by a **tool** contains all the **MuG VRE** tools that can be called from this particular file. **MC-DNA** is one of the **tools** that can be selected. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04130e8af725.21134042.png) Once you selected the tool **MC-DNA** you can choose between 'Create Trajectory' and 'Create Structure'. If 'Create Trajectory' selected a field 'Number of structures' appears where the user can choose how many snapshots are going to be simulated. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04131a96cde5.79741321.png)

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Results
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In the ‘View Results’ section, you can download all the analysis results and the structure/trajectory in a compressed tar.gz file. In this file you can find the figures of the bending analysis: The results depend on the type of operations the user chooses to execute MC-DNA. [Create Structure](#anchor1) [Create Trajectory](#anchor2)   If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***create_str01.png***: Bending distribution of all 5/10bp segments of the simulated DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010). The x-axis shows the bending in degree, the y-axis the density. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041a4eb2ea41.86588142.png) * ***create_str02.png***: Bending of 5/10bp segments along the DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010) (Note: n here is the last bp of the segment bnx(10) ). title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Help
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. Furthermore, the obtained structure and/or trajectory can be used as an input to **NAflex** for a more detailed analysis. ![{w:600}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046f74a7aa28.10745002.png)

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010) (Note: n here is the last bp of the segment bnx(10) ). title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Results
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In the ‘View Results’ section, you can download all the analysis results and the structure/trajectory in a compressed tar.gz file. In this file you can find the figures of the bending analysis: The results depend on the type of operations the user chooses to execute MC-DNA. [Create Structure](#anchor1) [Create Trajectory](#anchor2)   If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***create_str01.png***: Bending distribution of all 5/10bp segments of the simulated DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010). The x-axis shows the bending in degree, the y-axis the density. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041a4eb2ea41.86588142.png) * ***create_str02.png***: Bending of 5/10bp segments along the DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010) (Note: n here is the last bp of the segment bnx(10) ). The x-axis shows the index of the basepair, the y-axis shows the bending in degree. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041bb9575091.47548585.png)   If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***create_traj01.png***: same as create_str01.png, here all snapshots of the trajectory are taken into accoutn. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cbbb2f0b4.02405084.png) * ***create_traj02.png***: same as create_str02.png, averaged over all snapshots of the trajectory. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cea5aed73.99266157.png) NOTE: For a more detailed analysis apart from bending use the output pdb or trajectory files as an input to *NAflex*.

title: Inputs
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References **MC-DNA** can be computed from a **DNA sequence**. # Accepted input file combinations **Combination ** *(File Type - Data Type)* ``` TXT DNA sequence ``` To run **MC-DNA** a `txt` file representing a **DNA sequence** needs to be selected in the **user workspace**. Associated to the **txt file**, at the right part of the workspace (in the same row), an **Actions button** represented by a **tool** contains all the **MuG VRE** tools that can be called from this particular file. **MC-DNA** is one of the **tools** that can be selected. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04130e8af725.21134042.png) Once you selected the tool **MC-DNA** you can choose between 'Create Trajectory' and 'Create Structure'. If 'Create Trajectory' selected a field 'Number of structures' appears where the user can choose how many snapshots are going to be simulated. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04131a96cde5.79741321.png)

title: Outputs
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046ab40f25d1.74493147.png) If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***mc_dna_eq_str.pdb***: structure with DNA in relaxed state. Can be visualized in NGL viewer ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf8a0359424.68527922.png) If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***mc_dna_str.dcd***: trajectory file (in GROMACS format). Can be visualized in NGL viewer together with 'mc_dna_str.pdb' * ***mc_dna_str.pdb***: first structure of the ensemble. Can be visualized it in NGL viewer * ***mc_dna_str.top***: topology file for DNA trajectory; necessary to visualize trajectory in NGL viewer. It is also necessary for Input to the analysis tool of nuclear acid structures and trajectories *NAflex*

title: Help
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. Furthermore, the obtained structure and/or trajectory can be used as an input to **NAflex** for a more detailed analysis. ![{w:600}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046f74a7aa28.10745002.png)

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Help
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. Furthermore, the obtained structure and/or trajectory can be used as an input to **NAflex** for a more detailed analysis. ![{w:600}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046f74a7aa28.10745002.png)

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

Associated to the **txt file**, at the right part of the workspace (in the same row), an **Actions button** represented by a **tool** contains all the **MuG VRE** tools that can be called from this particular file. **MC-DNA** is one of the **tools** that can be selected. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04130e8af725.21134042.png) Once you selected the tool **MC-DNA** you can choose between 'Create Trajectory' and 'Create Structure'. title: Help
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. Furthermore, the obtained structure and/or trajectory can be used as an input to **NAflex** for a more detailed analysis. ![{w:600}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046f74a7aa28.10745002.png)

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Results
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In the ‘View Results’ section, you can download all the analysis results and the structure/trajectory in a compressed tar.gz file. In this file you can find the figures of the bending analysis: The results depend on the type of operations the user chooses to execute MC-DNA. [Create Structure](#anchor1) [Create Trajectory](#anchor2)   If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***create_str01.png***: Bending distribution of all 5/10bp segments of the simulated DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010). The x-axis shows the bending in degree, the y-axis the density. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041a4eb2ea41.86588142.png) * ***create_str02.png***: Bending of 5/10bp segments along the DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010) (Note: n here is the last bp of the segment bnx(10) ). The x-axis shows the index of the basepair, the y-axis shows the bending in degree. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041bb9575091.47548585.png)   If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***create_traj01.png***: same as create_str01.png, here all snapshots of the trajectory are taken into accoutn. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cbbb2f0b4.02405084.png) * ***create_traj02.png***: same as create_str02.png, averaged over all snapshots of the trajectory. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cea5aed73.99266157.png) NOTE: For a more detailed analysis apart from bending use the output pdb or trajectory files as an input to *NAflex*.

content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References **MC-DNA** can be computed from a **DNA sequence**. # Accepted input file combinations **Combination ** *(File Type - Data Type)* ``` TXT DNA sequence ``` To run **MC-DNA** a `txt` file representing a **DNA sequence** needs to be selected in the **user workspace**. Associated to the **txt file**, at the right part of the workspace (in the same row), an **Actions button** represented by a **tool** contains all the **MuG VRE** tools that can be called from this particular file. **MC-DNA** is one of the **tools** that can be selected. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04130e8af725.21134042.png) Once you selected the tool **MC-DNA** you can choose between 'Create Trajectory' and 'Create Structure'. If 'Create Trajectory' selected a field 'Number of structures' appears where the user can choose how many snapshots are going to be simulated. ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a04131a96cde5.79741321.png)

title: Outputs
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046ab40f25d1.74493147.png) If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***mc_dna_eq_str.pdb***: structure with DNA in relaxed state. Can be visualized in NGL viewer ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf8a0359424.68527922.png) If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***mc_dna_str.dcd***: trajectory file (in GROMACS format). Can be visualized in NGL viewer together with 'mc_dna_str.pdb' * ***mc_dna_str.pdb***: first structure of the ensemble. Can be visualized it in NGL viewer * ***mc_dna_str.top***: topology file for DNA trajectory; necessary to visualize trajectory in NGL viewer. It is also necessary for Input to the analysis tool of nuclear acid structures and trajectories *NAflex*

title: Help
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References ![](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/59fdf070e84cd6.10508109.png) **MC-DNA** is a tool to rapidly create all-atom B-DNA conformations of a sequence of interest. With this tool the user can obtain ground state structure or a molecular dynamics like trajectory of many posible conformations. With the use of a Monte Carlo algorithm on the bp-step parameters this tool runs up to 105 faster than conventional Molecular Dynamics providing similar accuracy. MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. Furthermore, the obtained structure and/or trajectory can be used as an input to **NAflex** for a more detailed analysis. ![{w:600}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a046f74a7aa28.10745002.png)

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Results
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In the ‘View Results’ section, you can download all the analysis results and the structure/trajectory in a compressed tar.gz file. In this file you can find the figures of the bending analysis: The results depend on the type of operations the user chooses to execute MC-DNA. [Create Structure](#anchor1) [Create Trajectory](#anchor2)   If 'Create Structure' chosen: * ***create_str01.png***: Bending distribution of all 5/10bp segments of the simulated DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010). The x-axis shows the bending in degree, the y-axis the density. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041a4eb2ea41.86588142.png) * ***create_str02.png***: Bending of 5/10bp segments along the DNA fiber. The bending angle of a segment of 10 base-pairs of DNA is calculated according to sqrt(bnx(10) 2 + bny(10) 2) while bnx(10) and bny(10) are calculated according to Equation (7) and (8) of Battistini et al., J Mol Bio (2010) (Note: n here is the last bp of the segment bnx(10) ). The x-axis shows the index of the basepair, the y-axis shows the bending in degree. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041bb9575091.47548585.png)   If 'Create Trajectory' chosen: * ***create_traj01.png***: same as create_str01.png, here all snapshots of the trajectory are taken into accoutn. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cbbb2f0b4.02405084.png) * ***create_traj02.png***: same as create_str02.png, averaged over all snapshots of the trajectory. ![{w:300}](/tools/tool_skeleton/help/img/5a041cea5aed73.99266157.png) NOTE: For a more detailed analysis apart from bending use the output pdb or trajectory files as an input to *NAflex*.

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

MC-DNA provides a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA structure with the underlying sequence of interest and displays its bending properties. title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

title: Method
content: Method Inputs Outputs Results References In MC-DNA, DNA is represented intrinsically at base pair step level. Rigid base-pairs are connected via elastic potentials modulating the interactions of neighboring base-pairs in a given tetramer environment. The six interactions are given by six base-pair step coordinates: three translational (shift, slide, rise) and three rotational (tilt, roll, twist) degrees of freedom. The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.

The parameters of the elastic potentials (stiffness constants and relaxed state) for each base-pair step with its nearest neighbors are derived from atomistic molecular dynamics simulations. MC-DNA runs a Metropolis Monte Carlo algorithm on the base-pair step parameters. It then tranforms the bp-step parameters of the final result of the algorithm into a three-dimensional all-atom representation of the DNA molecule. Important note: even though the outputs of this program are atomistic, the smallest unit of this model is a base-pair. Options: * **Create Structure**: Creates a single structure of DNA in a relaxed state (relaxed state is defined as the state of minimum potential energy according to the bp-step parameters) * **Create Trajectory**: Creates a certain number of DNA structures (specify the number of structures in the corresponding field). The sampling is done via Monte Carlo moves on the bp-step parameters of the DNA. This option is recommended if average properties of the DNA want to be obtained.
